frame.name: Time_vector
frame.definition:
<def-root>An <fen>Event</fen> is identified as occurring at a particular <fen>Distance</fen> and in a particular <fen>Direction</fen> from a <fen>Landmark_event</fen>. The lexical units incorporate the <fen>Direction</fen> and, in some cases, the <fen>Landmark_event</fen>. This frame builds on the Direction frame, further specifying the Domain as Time. This frame will receive some of the lexical units currently found in Relative_time.
<ex> <fex name="Event">Tell me that</fex> <fex name="Distance">a week</fex> <fex name="Direction"><t>from</t></fex> <fex name="Landmark_event">now</fex>. </ex> <ex> <fex name="Distance">Some twelve months</fex> <fex name="Direction"><t>after</t></fex> <fex name="Landmark_event">I had graduated</fex>, <fex name="Event">I had my first job interview</fex></ex></def-root>

FE.name: Landmark_event
FE.definition:
<def-root>This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate the reference point in which the Event is anchored.
<ex> Sue is going to pick me up again two days <t>from</t> <fex name="Landmark_event">tomorrow</fex>. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Distance
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE marks expressions that indicate the amount of time that lies between the Target and the <fen>Landmark_event</fen>.
<ex>Peter will meet me <fex name="Distance">a week</fex> <t>from</t> today </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Direction
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE marks expressions that indicate whether the Target is prior or subsequent to the <fen>Landmark_event</fen> on the time line.
<ex> Mom last called me a week <fex name="Direction"><t>ago</t></fex>. </ex></def-root>

FE.name: Event
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE indicates the <fen>Event</fen> temporally located with respect to the <fen>Landmark_event</fen>. <ex><fex name="Event">The incident</fex> <m>was</m> several years <t>ago</t>.</ex></def-root>
